unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate and apply basic experimental research skills to test hypotheses in neuroscience.
Understand the core methods employed in neuroscience.
Explain key terminology and basic principles of neuroscience.
Describe the basic structure and function of the central nervous system with an emphasis on the human brain.
Analyse and interpret scientific information and research in neuroscience.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading/Preparation for lectures (2 hrs per week)

assessments.description: 1 hr multiple choice exam, conducted in class.
2 hr exam, conducted during the official exam period. Combination of multiple choice and short answer questions.
Short (1-2 page), highly structured lab activity sheets completed in class. 1 activity sheet per lab. Graded on C/NC basis. Students may miss 1 lab activity without penalty.
1 hr multiple choice exam, conducted online.

Short online multiple quizzes covering basic content completed before each class lecture. Designed to provide routine assessment and feedback. Graded on C/NC basis with 50% correct threshold for C. 10 quizzes in total; 10-20 MC questions; no make-up quizzes; students may drop 2 lowest quizzes without penalty.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances, North Ryde

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit forms a 2-unit sequence with COGS1000 and provides an intensive introduction to the fundamentals of modern neuroscience, with a focus on the structure and function of the human brain. Topics include neuroanatomy, neural signalling, sensory processing, neural control of movement, and brain development and evolution. Tutorials include hands-on research activities in which students will have the opportunity to act as both researchers and experimental participants.
data.title: Introduction to Neuroscience 2

description: This unit forms a 2-unit sequence with COGS1000 and provides an intensive introduction to the fundamentals of modern neuroscience, with a focus on the structure and function of the human brain. Topics include neuroanatomy, neural signalling, sensory processing, neural control of movement, and brain development and evolution. Tutorials include hands-on research activities in which students will have the opportunity to act as both researchers and experimental participants.
title: Introduction to Neuroscience 2
